items.title: 🎬 Information Architecture Basics (8 mins.)
Information Architecture Overview
items.content:
Defining Information Architecture

Nailing down a good definition of IA (Information Architecture) is a little bit like trying to define the word 'design.' The answer depends on who you ask and when you ask them. Dan Ramsden–the the creative director of the BBC–defines it like this:

Information architecture is the set of relationships that generate the coherence which turns the “parts” into the “whole”. It is also the consideration of how that whole will relate and function within the “next biggest context(s)” which contain it.

Let's break that definition into three parts and examine them:

  1. Set of relationships
  2. Generate coherence/parts into the whole
  3. How the whole functions within the next biggest context

Set of relationships

Here's an image of books on a bookshelf. They aren't in any particular order or grouping. Right now, the only relationships they have to each other is

  1. they have a private owner
  2. they all sit on the same shelf
  3. they are all books

Now, whether or not these existing relationships are meaningful or helpful depends on the context. If there were also books from the library on this shelf, then the relationship "they have a private owner" becomes meaningful.

Source: Unsplash

 

Now let's make a list of some different ways we might possibly arrange (architect) the books.

  • Alphabetically (by title or author)
  • By physical attributes (height, color, number of pages)
  • By subject
  • By time it takes to read
  • Purchase price, least expensive to most

How you choose to arrange the books impacts the utility of being able to find the book you want quickly. BUT that assumes the intention is to find books quickly. Maybe your intention is to scan every title and pick randomly for serendipity. If you group by subject, you're forced to consider whether or not you're interested in that subject before reading the titles within the group. So which intentions should you optimize for and why?

In essence, this is IA work–intentional design choices about object relationships in order to optimize for a set of intentions or purposes. Or said another way, rearranging information creates new information.

Coherence which turns the "parts" into a "whole"

Information Architecture always exists, but it’s not always created intentionally. When IA is not considered, researched, designed, and tested, you run a good chance of undermining the message or utility of your designs.

With the books, the parts are the individual books. The whole is how well your arrangement matches the mental model of others and how well it fits a larger context. A system in which one shelf was arranged by title, another shelf by author, and a third shelf by color wouldn't be coherent to anyone else trying to find a book.

Coherence means that the "rules" of how information is organized are clear. It's easy to see the "whole." Interestingly, this is also how the Gestalt Theory function in visual design, as an organized whole that is perceived as more than the sum of its parts.

How the whole functions within the next biggest context

The concept of coherence extends information architecture into the next biggest context. If you order a drink from the Starbucks website, it should be easy to find the order from the Starbucks app, then pay for that order with a digital Starbucks gift card someone sent via email. The reason you can do this so easily and quickly is because the designers use a coherent information architecture. The digital navigation, hierarchy, and terminology work well across all three contexts.

Information architecture is the only field I’m aware of that is concerned with the structural integrity of meaning across contexts. —Jorge Jarango

Information architecture is the art and science of organizing and labeling information to make it findable and understandable. For digital spaces like websites, intranets, online communities, and software, IA organizes and presents information to support usability.

In nearly every interaction with a digital product, users are seeking information in one form or another. As designers, we must continually ask ourselves how to help them access that information as easily as possible.

 

IA is vital for the user experience

It allows users to navigate websites and apps easily, find the information they are looking for faster, and complete their intended tasks with less confusion and frustration. Like a real-world architect, you're planning the informational "space" where people will dwell, be it in digital or real life.

IA delivers better results for business goals

When information is easy to find, and the navigation matches users' mental models, it improves the metrics that businesses care about the most. For instance, conversion rate (new visitors making their first purchase) and retention rate (existing user making another purchase) for e-commerce websites, dropoff rate for businesses who want their users to finish specific processes.

Good IA can save the company both time and money, which they would have spent fixing and improving.

IA considerations

  • Structure and Organization is about how information is categorized, classified, and bundled.
  • Labeling systems is how information gets represented with terminology appropriate for the intended audience.
  • Navigation systems are how users browse, move through, and find information.
  • Search systems support information-seeking behavior.

items.title: Principles of Information Architecture
items.content:
What makes information architecture useful?

“The use of well-established design principles increases the probability that a design will be successful.” – Lidwell, Holden, and Butler, Universal Principles of Design

In 2010 information architecture was a fairly new and still developing field. Dan Brown, an Information Architect and a founder and principal at EightShapes, identified a need for information architecture to maintain a universal set of principles to measure the success of any project, similar to the way white space, typography, and color theory serve as guiding principles for visual design.

Below is a summary of Brown’s Eight Principles of Information Architecture, with quotes from his original text.

The principle of objects

Treat content as a living, breathing thing with a lifecycle, behaviors and attributes.

Many digital products offer vast amounts of content, and not every type of content has the same relationship with other parts of the product or can be organized in the same way. It’s important to identify what types of content are found within your product, to understand the mental models users associate with each type of content, and to establish a plan for organizing today’s content and supporting tomorrow’s growth.

Information architects evaluate the existing content a product offers using both content inventories and content audits.

Content inventories

A content inventory is a quantitative process of cataloging the entire contents of a digital product in a shareable, accessible format.

Content inventories serve as blueprints for a product’s information architecture, and enables teams to understand what types of content currently exist and how that information is organized.

Content audits

A content audit is a qualitative process of evaluating the content listed in the inventory. Audits identify content that needs updating, gaps that new content could fill, and outdated content that could be marked for removal.

The principle of choices

Create pages that offer meaningful choices to users, keeping the range of choices available focused on a particular task.

The principle of choices insists that the options offered to users should always be specific, meaningful, and limited in number, as too many choices can overwhelm a user.

This principle functions similarly to Hick’s Law, which states that the time it takes users to make a decision increases with the number and complexity of choices. To avoid increasing the user’s cognitive load,

  • Minimize choices wherever possible
  • Highlight recommended options
  • Break complex tasks into smaller steps

The principle of disclosure

Show only enough information to help people understand what kinds of information they’ll find as they dig deeper.

The concept of slowly presenting information to users only as it’s needed, rather than overwhelming them with details and choices up front, is known as progressive disclosure.

For example, Instagram’s home screen presents the options users are most likely to interact with, and allows new users to get up and running with a new post fairly quickly. Features that only pertain to advanced users, or users facing a problem, are kept under the user settings icon.

The principle of exemplars

Describe the contents of categories by showing examples of the contents.

The distinction between category names is occasionally so obvious that no description is needed. If users are choosing between Books and Movies, little supporting content is necessary to help them make their choice, provided the navigation links are designed properly to invite interaction.

However, what about brand-specific names? Can Hyundai be confident that casual web visitors immediately recognize the distance between a Venue, Kona, and Tucson?

Probably not, which is why Hyundai helps users decide by offering photos of the vehicles as well as a couple of key characteristics, including price and gas mileage (or range per charge, in the case of the Kona Electric.)

The principle of front doors

Assume at least half of the website’s visitors will come through some page other than the home page.

In the web usability textbook Don’t Make Me Think, author Steve Krug offers something he calls a Trunk Test to gauge the effectiveness of a web page’s navigation.

Rather than judging the homepage, Krug recommends choosing a page deep within the bowels of a web site, and then attempting to answer the following questions without hesitation:

  • What site is this?
  • What page am I on?
  • What are the major sections of this site?
  • What are my options at this level? (Local navigation)
  • Where am I in the scheme of things? (“You are here” indicators)
  • How can I search?

Many sites focus on answering these questions thoroughly on the homepage, but the problem with that approach is many users never see your homepage. They may have arrived via a bookmark, a link shared on social media, or by clicking a banner ad.

Dan Brown’s principle of front doors advises you to assume at least half your visitors didn’t see your homepage, and to design navigation accordingly.

The principle of multiple classification

Offer users several different classification schemes to browse the site’s content.

Users shopping from e-commerce sites, for example, can typically be divided into two categories: those who know exactly what they’re looking for, and those who don’t.

Consider a user shopping for hiking shorts at REI’s website. Users with a particular item in mind will most likely use the search bar across the top of the page.

For users who aren’t sure what they want, they might discover the Hiking Clothing category under Camp & Hike. Alternately, they might find discounted hiking shorts under Deals, or they might browse to the Men or Women category and then shop by activity. Keep in mind a choice between Men and Women’s clothing might not support the needs of nonbinary users, however.

Nielsen Norman Group describes navigation allowing multiple ways to find the same content as a polyhierarchy, and suggests polyhierarchies are particularly appropriate for hard-to-classify content.

The principle of focused navigation

Don’t mix apples and oranges in your navigation scheme.

Rather than creating one massive menu with links to every piece of site content, create menus specific to smaller groups of content, and position those menus where the user is most likely to need them.

Don’t include menu items that are irrelevant to the navigation category. If a user clicks a dropdown button labeled Shop, don’t include a sublink called Contact Us. Reserve contact links for places like the page footer or a product returns page.

When designing navigation, it’s important to select the proper navigational element for each type of content.

Global navigation

Global navigation is available on all pages and enables users to get to the main sections of a website from any page.

Local navigation

Local navigation is contextual to the user’s location. It indicates to users where they are and reveals what other content is nearby in the information hierarchy.

Local navigation provides access to deeper parts of an information architecture system that would increase cognitive load if included on the home page or in the global navigation.

Contextual navigation

Links that don’t fit neatly into global or local navigation, but rather make sense only in a particular context, are referred to as contextual navigation.

Lists of related products on a shopping page and related articles on a news page are two examples of contextual navigation.

The principle of growth

Assume the content you have today is a small fraction of the content you will have tomorrow.

When deciding on categorization and navigation schemes for your web content, do your best to consider additional types of content that may eventually be added, including new categories of content that might not be reflected by what’s currently part of your site or application. Your navigation and information architecture should be scalable, able to accommodate growth without becoming cumbersome or unwieldy.

If totally future-proofing your informational structures sounds impossible, by the way, that’s because it probably is. The eight principles of information architecture are meant to be referred to frequently. And when in doubt, refer to the first principle: treat your content as living and evolving, and conduct content inventories and audits as often as needed.

items.title: Content Inventories and Audits
items.content:
Why evaluate content?

The purpose of evaluating content of a digital product is to understand, organize, and evaluate the content you’re currently working with.

Content inventories and content audits are usually conducted on a product that’s already been launched, meaning you can use these techniques to document where the content currently lives and how effective each piece of content currently is. Is it helping reach business goals? What about user goals?

What’s the difference?

The terms content inventory and content audit sometimes get used interchangeably, but they are not synonyms.

A content inventory is a quantitative analysis of a digital product. Conducting a content inventory involves cataloging each piece of content. Doing so answers the question what content do we currently have?

A content audit is a qualitative analysis of a digital product. Conducting a content inventory involves measuring the effectiveness of each piece of content. Doing so answers the question is this content valuable?

Both processes are usually completed together. The content inventory tells design teams the depth and breadth of the current content. Following the content inventory with a content audit allows design teams to understand the quality of each piece of content, and begin working on improvements.

Conducting a content inventory

Choose a spreadsheet

Your content inventory should take place in a shareable, collaborative spreadsheet such as Google Sheets. This allows multiple team members to review the information, and potentially allows your team to divide up the work. Conducting a content inventory on a large site will take some time.

Decide on categories

Your spreadsheet header will contain the categories of information your team will document for your web content.

Possible categories for your content inventory spreadsheet include (but are not limited to) the following:

  • ID number: some teams like to provide each content item with a unique identifying number.
  • Location: where is this content located?
  • Subject matter or topic.
  • Content type: is this a landing page? A blog post? A signup form?
  • Metadata: page title, page description, SEO keywords
  • Media: does this page contain additional assets like videos, audio files, or PDFs?
  • Owner: who is responsible for this content? Does it belong to a particular author?
  • Date last updated.

Populate the spreadsheet

Now for the time-consuming part. It’s best to start either with the content that exists at higher levels in the site’s hierarchy and work your way down, or else work first on content that matters most to the success of the business and the satisfaction of your users.

Conducting a content audit

Now that you’ve categorized the content of your digital product, the next step is to measure the effectiveness of each piece of content. One possible approach might be adding additional qualitative categories to your existing content analysis spreadsheet.

When rating the effectiveness of your content, it’s important for your team to devise a scale for prioritizing fixes, such as

  • ⛔️ Fix immediately
  • ⚠️ Fix gradually
  • 🗓 Fix eventually
  • ✅ Leave alone

The types of fixes your team will identify will typically fall into one of two categories.

Best practices

  • Content presentation
    • Does your writing make use of plain language?
    • Do your headings properly describe the associated content?
    • Have you chunked lengthier content into more digestible pieces?
    • Does your use of white space support effective visual hierarchy?
  • Accessibility
    • Does your content use a proper heading structure?
    • Does your link text accurately describe linked content?
    • Is there proper contrast between your text and background?
    • Are you providing alt descriptions for images?
    • Are you providing captions for videos? And is autoplay turned off?

Quality standards

  • User needs: is this content helping users reach their goals?
  • Business goals: when reviewing analytics, how is this content performing? Are users clicking the right links and visiting the right pages?
  • Branding: is the voice and tone of this content consistent with brand principles? Is the visual design consistent with the brand style guide?

items.title: Project Brief: HAYDN
items.content:
Overview

During Studio I, you will be working on two projects for the same client: a one-page marketing website and a mobile application for the Android platform.

  • In Module 7, you will create a usability test plan for the client's mobile application for the Android platform. In addition, you will perform both of the following tasks for the client’s one-page marketing website:
    • Open card sort
    • Mid-fidelity desktop wireframe
  • In Module 8, you will create a high-fidelity mockup of the client’s one-page marketing website.
  • In Module 9, you will perform all of the following tasks for the client’s mobile application for the Android platform:
    • High-fidelity prototypes
    • Usability test
    • Usability test report

At the end of the Phase you may be asked present your findings to an audience, depending on the requirements determined by your instructor.

The Brief

HAYDN is an AI-driven content generator that helps anyone who has to write content, to do so quickly, easily and effectively. HAYDN has been trained on over 1 million pieces of content and can help you write content in minutes that is both high quality and engaging.

For this project, you will design the landing page for their new marketing website and prototype a new feature idea for their mobile application.

Their UX team has already created low-fidelity wireframes for the marketing site. And the marketing team has drafted starter copy for you to use.

Existing assets

  1. Low-fidelity wireframes for marketing site
  2. Wireframes for mobile app
  3. Site copy
  4. Style Guide

Target Audience

HAYDN’s primary target audience is marketers of all kinds: email, social media, bloggers, content writers, social media managers, and more.

You may conduct additional research to better understand your target user or competitive research in HAYDN’s market space if you wish, but this is not a project requirement.

items.title: 🎬 Navigation and Sitemaps (5 mins.)
Sitemaps
items.content:
First steps: structural audits

A structural audit is a formal review of a site focused on menus, flows, links, and hierarchies. The point is to try to understand a system the way users experience it, before trying to improve it. It’s the precursor to building a new sitemap, if you are starting with an existing product.

Information Architects typically use spreadsheet software to organize the audit. If you ever find yourself needing to do a structural audit, Lisa Maria Martin has an excellent process she teaches in Everyday Information Architecture: Auditing for Structure.

Building Sitemaps

A sitemap is an artifact for communicating the structure of a website or application. It is typically a hierarchical list of pages, with each page represented by a URL and possibly some associated metadata (e.g., last modified date). A sitemap can also be used to provide additional information about the site, such as which sections or pages are most popular.

Creating a sitemap can be helpful in designing and planning a website or application. It can also be useful for communicating the structure of an existing site to stakeholders. Sitemaps are an opportunity to develop shared vocabulary and terminology with designers, developers, copywriters, marketers, project managers, and product managers.

Sitemaps are not meant to capture every possible path. Nor are they meant to be a substitute for a well-designed user interface. Rather, sitemaps should focus on the main navigation paths and content areas of a site. Understanding the hierarchy of pages gives you a baseline for how users will potentially move through your site.

There are a few documentation styles you can use, depending on how much detail you need to show.

Outline style

  • 0.0 Home
  • 1.0 Shop
    • 1.1 Coffee Subscriptions
    • 1.2 Coffee
      • 1.2.1 Regions
      • 1.2.2 Processing
      • 1.2.3 Type
    • 1.3 Brew Tools
    • 1.4 Ceramics and Mugs
    • 1.5 Coffee Finder
    • 1.6 Gift Cards
    • 1.7 Gift Subscriptions
    • 1.8 Corporate Gift Program
  • 2.0 Subscriptions
  • 3.0 Locations
  • 4.0 Learn

Spreadsheets

Spreadsheets are your best option for large sites with lots of navigation.

Box-and-arrow diagrams

These diagrams work best for smaller sites. They are visually appealing and great for presenting high-level structure to stakeholders. Rather than adding all the detail to a single diagram, the better approach is usually to have multiple pages. The first page should show one-level deep, and subsequent pages can show details within each navigation structure.

Add a legend to your diagram if you encode information using color, icons, connectors, borders, or shading that isn’t readily apparent to people you share it with.

Recommendations

  1. Use page ID’s for consistency
  2. Differentiate between single pages and collections. For collections of content, like blogs, events, articles, you can overlap several boxes to suggest multiple pages. Or write the page type in brackets [News articles].
  3. Communicate context. Don’t expect the sitemap to communicate everything. You may need to present additional research or rationale for your decisions.
  4. Tools like Mural, Miro, Figjam, and Whimsical are making it easier to create large sitemaps with the ability to zoom in and out.

items.title: 🎬 Search (5 mins.)
🎬 Combining Methods (3 mins.)
Tree Testing
items.content:
What is tree testing?

Tree testing is a research method that allows design teams to evaluate the hierarchy and findability of topics in a website or app.

In tree testing, a text-only version of a digital product’s hierarchy is placed in front of test participants, who are asked to identify categories or pages where they would expect to find particular items or pieces of content.

A tree test is a useful follow-up to open card sorting, because it

  • Evaluates hierarchies using task scenarios in a method similar to usability testing
  • Uncovers flaws with information architecture schemes well in advance of designing page layouts or navigation menus

The tree testing process

Define the tree

Your tree should be a complete list of all your product’s main content categories and subcategories. These categories and subcategories are often informed by the results of an open card sort.

Even if you are interested in testing only a specific section of the tree, be sure to include all sections. Users often evaluate category labels by comparing them to nearby alternatives. If your product contains both Products and Services categories, and you choose to test only Products, you won’t be sure whether users understand the distinction between Products and Services when completing the provided task.

Define the tasks

Tree testing tasks typically involve asking the user to locate an important product or service within your navigation. Each task should use clear language outlining what the user should look for. Be as brief as possible–no need to provide a lengthy story. And avoid giving instructions or using the names of interface labels in your task scenario.

Nielsen Norman Group offers the following examples of possible phrases for evaluating the Starting a Business Category on when tree testing the website navigation for the New Mexico State Government:

  • “Find information about starting a business.”
    • This example hints at the answer by using the category name within the task description.
  • “You are moving to Santa Fe next year, and once you arrive you would like to supplement your income by opening a side business providing lawn-care services. Find out what regulations you will need to follow.”
    • This task description is unnecessarily detailed. Users might have trouble understanding their primary task.
  • “You are considering opening a lawn-care service. See if there are any resources on this site that can help you begin the process.”
    • This feels about right. The task is understandable, and the description doesn’t give clues on where to find the answer.

Tree tests can be conducted quickly. Each testing each user ideally won’t last longer than 20 minutes, and can include up to 10 individual tasks.

Conducting a tree test

Tree tests can be conducted using paper, or any prototyping software. Alternatively, services like Userzoom and Treejack provide dashboards for gathering and analyzing tree test results.

Tree tests can be either moderated or unmoderated. In unmoderated tree tests, users receive a link to the tree test and complete the provided tasks on their own time.

While unmoderated testing software is more efficient than a human at keeping track of exactly where users click, unmoderated sessions lack the ability to encourage users to think aloud or the opportunity to ask follow-up questions.

One way to mitigate this is to provide users with a short follow-up survey providing a list of navigation labels and asking users to identify which ones they found confusing.

items.title: Introducing Taxonomies
items.content:
What is a taxonomy?

As discussed in previous readings, a common mistake businesses make is organizing the contents of a digital product in a manner that makes sense to the business. For information architecture to succeed, the categorization and organization of information needs to match the user’s mental model.

Open card sorts are an excellent exercise for creating taxonomies, as the process will allow design teams insight into user mental models for grouping and categorizing information.

A taxonomy is a method of grouping, classifying, and labeling information based on shared characteristics. Taxonomies are often visualized in a tree structure, presenting a hierarchy of categorized information.

In her Optimal Workshop article “How to develop a taxonomy for your information architecture”, Ashlea McKay describes taxonomies this way:

Think of an IA as a house. The taxonomy determines which pieces of furniture belong in each room and we navigate around the house via doorways and hallways. It all fits together to create one shared environment.

For a website example, think of an online shoe store. The shoes might be organized and labelled by color, size, style, season or collection — that’s the taxonomy.

Tree tests are used to test the effectiveness of taxonomies. Can users find what they’re looking for using your product’s current or proposed organization scheme?

Types of taxonomies

Flat taxonomy

Flat taxonomies consist of only top-level categories spread out horizontally. No single subject is covered in enough depth to necessitate subcategories.

Flat taxonomies are useful only for simple websites without many user needs to satisfy. A veterinarian’s office, for example, may only offer a few categories such as About Us, Book an Appointment, Location, and Services. Users don’t need more than a superficial amount of detail from each page.

Hierarchical taxonomy

Many larger websites are organized based on a hierarchical taxonomy. Hierarchical taxonomies begin with broad top-level categories, most of which will contain more specific subcategories.

A hierarchical taxonomy could be used to classify and organize the animal kingdom. In the illustration below, vertebrates are divided into the broad categories of warm-blooded and cold-blooded animals. Warm-blooded animals are then divided into the more specific categories of mammals, birds, and fish, each of which contain a number of animals.

Complex websites often can’t be classified in a straightforward manner the way the animal kingdom can. While the Tigers child category fits in only the Mammals parent category, an e-commerce product like a video game might be found by users browsing in multiple ways.

When some child nodes belong to more than one parent node, this is known as a polyhierarchy.In this example from Target.com, the Nintendo Switch is listed under both the Video Games and Electronics top-level categories.

Network taxonomy

Modern web apps featuring vast amounts of streaming content often don’t find hierarchical taxonomies useful for categorization. Take Netflix: while it’s possible for a user to choose a broad category such as Drama, this category covers a staggering number of films and television shows, and the methods of subcategorization are not obvious or universally agreed upon. In addition, one single television show might fit into many different categories.

While Netflix does contain some hierarchically grouped content, browsing Netflix is primarily based on a network taxonomy in which content is grouped based on associative categories.

So while hit shows like Luke Cage, Stranger Things, and The Queen’s Gambit might not be comfortably grouped using a hierarchical taxonomy, they could easily appear together under associative categories like New & Popular, My List, or Recommended For You.

Facet taxonomy

Online experiences that rely primarily on searching and filtering are examples of facet taxonomies. In facet taxonomies, the same item may appear numerous times depending on the particulars of the search term and filters applied.

In a facet taxonomy diagram, the search term appears at the center of a web, with associated taxonomies drawn around it.

For example, most Yelp users seeking a restaurant recommendation begin with a search term matching their needs as well as their current location. A particular cafe might appear in numerous searches depending on the user’s search term (cafe, restaurant, brunch, bagels) and combination of filters (kid friendly, outdoor space, takes reservations, wheelchair accessible).

items.title: Working with Metadata
items.content:
The role of metadata within taxonomies

Taxonomies provide a organizational structure for a digital product. On very simple websites using flat taxonomies, categorizing information is as simple as assigning a single page of content to each category.

For polyhierarchies, network taxonomies, and facet taxonomies, however, organizing information is far more challenging. Each piece of information needs to be assigned defining attributes and classification, which is known as metadata.

Metadata is defined as data that describes other data so it can be categorized. Think about an online clothing store: each individual item of clothing should be assigned specific data so users can locate it by searching or browsing.

  • Name: Unisex Red T-Shirt
  • Color: Red
  • Size: Medium
  • Type: Shirt
    • Shirt Type: T-Shirt
  • Material: Cotton
  • Price: $20
  • On Sale: No

In the above example, searching for shirts, for red clothing, or for cotton clothing would all turn up the above t-shirt in the search results. A filter for items under $25 would include this shirt, while a filter for sale items would eliminate it from the results.

Depending on the user’s needs when shopping, we could continue adding metadata such as season (this shirt is appropriate for summer, but not winter) or occasion (this shirt is casual, not formal).

Metadata and navigation

If metadata is meaningful to most site visitors, it belongs in the primary navigation. Returning to the example of our t-shirt metadata, not every user will be searching specifically for cotton clothing, or for casual wear. It might be helpful to provide these options somewhere, but many users will ignore them, or perhaps use them to filter down a large list of search results.

However, a user shopping for shirts would likely prefer to exclude other articles of clothing from their results. The choice between categories of clothing–shirts, pants, swimwear, coats–matters to almost every user, and therefore belongs in the primary navigation as a place to begin browsing.

Depending on the focus of a particular website, however, the metadata critical to most users might vary. Base your decision-making on conversations with target users rather than assumptions.

Filtering options

Websites with vast amounts of content and polyhierarchical taxonomies like e-commerce sites benefit from allowing users to filter lengthy lists of search results or items found.

Filtering options should reflect the metadata assigned to your site content. Based on the t-shirt example described above, we might need to provide filters for shirt type, color, size, price, material, price, and whether the product is on sale.

Should we provide an additional filter for clothing category? That depends on context. If the user browses by clicking “Shirts” from the primary navigation, then no. But if the user searches for a term like ”Red Nikes”, this could conceivably bring up products across multiple categories (red Nike sneakers, red Nike jackets), so allowing users to filter by product category could prove useful.

In addition to keeping filtering options relevant to your metadata, Nielsen Norman Group offers a few additional tips for creating useful filters:

  • Customize filters based on the content type. Shoe sizes work differently than t-shirt sizes, for example. Make sure you're allowing users to filter based on metadata that’s relevant to the current product category.
  • Avoid vague category labels. When searching for sandals at DSW’s website, users struggled to understand the difference between “Item Type“ and ”Style”. DSW’s Style category offered very specific kinds of shoes, but not the general category “sandals” that the participant wanted.
  • Prioritize filter categories. Options higher at the list will receive more attention. Keep the categories that will appeal to the broadest spectrum of users near the top, while more technical specifications that appeal to advanced users should stay near the bottom.
  • Do your research. The metadata that categorizes your content, and the filter categories and values available to your users, should be based on user understanding of what you have to offer. Do enough research to be able to answer the following questions:
    • Which characteristics have the greatest impact on user decision-making?
    • What words do users use to describe these characteristics?
    • Do users understand our existing labels?

Card Sorting
items.content:
Matching user mental models

Too often, businesses sort online content based on criteria that makes sense to the business, rather than considering the user’s mental model–that is, how the user believes the current system operates and is organized.

Card sorting is a technique for understanding user mental models by gaining user feedback on how they understand your content and expect it to be categorized.

In a card sort, study participants group individually labeled cards according to criteria that makes sense to them. The knowledge of how users structure the provided information helps design teams create an information architecture that aligns with user expectations.

Conducting an open card sort

Prepare the cards

On a set of sticky notes or index cards, write the name of each individual content topic found within your digital product.

Do your best to avoid topics that sound too similar to each other, as participants tend to automatically group those together.

Recruit users

Nielsen Norman Group recommends testing 15 target users to obtain meaningful data from a card sort.

That number is 3 times as many users as a typical usability study: most usability tests can be run effectively with only 5 users.

Have the user group the cards

Let the user know there are no sorting rules:

  • Some piles can be larger than others.
  • The user can change their mind while they work and move cards around.
  • Some cards can be left unsorted.
    • If a card is repeatedly left unsorted in multiple tests, either the topic name is confusing, or the topic doesn’t share similarities with any other cards.

Have the user name the groups

This exercise is to better understand the user reasoning motivating each grouping. Users aren’t likely to come up with effective category labels. That’s a task for your design team.

Have the user reflect on their choices

Ask the user to explain their groupings, and have them call special attention to cards that were difficult to categorize.

Alternately, you might consider to have the user think aloud while grouping the cards, rather than explaining their reasoning retrospectively.

Open vs. closed card sorts

The process described above is an open card sort. In open card sorting, no prenamed categories are provided. Users are free to group the cards however they like, and name the categories however they choose. Open cart sorting is the most common type of card sort.

In a closed card sort, users sort cards into predefined categories. This type of card sort does a poor job of revealing user mental models in categorizing topics, but it can help design teams review how well a category structure supports existing content.

Closed card sorts are probably most helpful to test the usefulness of features such as search filters. To evaluate the effectiveness of category names as part of existing navigation structure, most UX researchers prefer using tree testing.

items.title: 🎬 What is a Wireframe? (11 mins.)
Introducing Wireframes
items.content:
What is a wireframe?

Wireframes are a skeletal outline of a webpage or app. Wireframes communicate a web page’s structure, layout, information architecture, user flow, and functionality.

Wireframes tend to be presented in greyscale, or with color minimally and intentionally applied, and to use plain, legible typography. Visual styling is reserved for later stages, and photographic imagery and illustrations are usually omitted from wireframes.

Wireframes are typically created using layout and prototyping tools such as Figma, although it’s possible for a wireframe to take the form of a carefully executed drawing.

Annotating wireframes

Since wireframes lack details and refinement found in a higher-fidelity design, wireframes are sometimes annotated so stakeholders may understand their purpose and functionality.

According to Annotated Wireframes for Product Design by Nick Babich, annotations are necessary when any of the following is unclear:

  • What the element is (This is a sign up button)
  • What the element does (This button allows users to register for a new account)
  • How the action is performed (When users click this button, they are directed to a sign up form)

Prototyping with wireframes

By adding functionality to wireframes, design teams can use them to gather feedback as medium-fidelity prototypes. Think of medium-fidelity prototypes as an intermediate stage between rough paper prototypes and a more polished, high-fidelity design.

Like low-fidelity paper prototypes, medium-fidelity wireframe prototypes allow design teams to gather more honest user feedback during usability tests. Users tend to hold back criticism if a design looks too polished.

Testing with medium-fidelity wireframe prototypes also allows design teams to catch usability issues relatively early, before significant time is invested in designing and developing a flawed solution.

When is medium-fidelity appropriate?

While medium-fidelity wireframe prototypes are faster to execute than polished high-fidelity prototypes, working in medium-fidelity is still a significant time investment. Your design team should thoroughly test lower-fidelity prototypes and eliminate early-stage problems and flawed assumptions before moving on to using medium-fidelity prototypes.

Medium-fidelity prototypes are used to refine the execution of solutions and create a prototype that structurally resembles a final product while still providing room for changing direction and testing options.

Questions to ask while wireframing

In her article The Definitive Guide: How To Make Your First Wireframe, author Rosie Allabarton offers a list of questions to keep in mind while designing a wireframe.

  • How can you organize the content to support your users’ goals?
  • Which information should be most prominent?
  • Where should your main message go?
  • What should the user see first when arriving at the page?
  • What will the user expect to see on certain areas of the page?
  • Which buttons or touch points does the user need to complete the desired actions?

items.title: Wireframe Elements
items.content:
Determine your goals, know your constraints

When creating wireframes, you’ll first need to understand the goals you’re aiming to achieve. What questions are you trying to answer? What ideas and assumptions do you need to test and validate?

Then, based on your goals and project constraints (i.e., budget, time, etc.), you’ll determine the areas to focus on and the level of fidelity and detail needed.

For the most part, wireframes use basic shapes (primarily boxes and lines) and shades of grey. Let’s review a few common wireframe elements.

Images

Images are commonly depicted as a box with an “x”, but may also depict a basic line drawing of scenery.

Videos

Video boxes should include a triangle in the center (indicating a play button) to differentiate it from static media.

Buttons/Call-to-actions (CTAs)

Buttons are often depicted as rectangles and, depending on the level of fidelity, will either include text that reads “CTA” or “button”, or the actual copy that will be used in the final product.

Note that usability testing should be done using the actual button label, as doing so enables your design team to test whether participants understood your messaging. Otherwise, you’re just testing a layout.

Body Text and Headers

In early, lower fidelity wireframes, text can be displayed as a series of lines or long rectangles.

While waiting for body copy, some designers will populate their wireframes with lorem ipsum, also known as dummy or filler text. Although, as discussed below, there are a number of reasons to avoid this practice.

The image above does visualize the idea that headers are differentiated from body text through the adjustment of visual weight (i.e. sizing, contrast, font weight) as well as proximity to blocks of body copy.

The trouble with lorem ipsum

“Lorem Ipsum is a way of delaying decisions about content.” – Chaymae Lougmani, Why Testing with Real Content Is Better Than Lorem Ipsum

While using lorem ipsum is tempting for designers, designing before content decisions have been made is less than optimal for a number of reasons.

  • Design is about communication. Lorem ipsum doesn’t communicate anything.
  • Testing body copy generates meaningful feedback. Did your messaging resonate with users? Did they understand your interface labels?
  • Designing for content length requires actual content. Decisions about line length, paragraph length, and element sizing should be made using actual copy, not an arbitrary and meaningless placeholder.
  • Voice and tone matters. Is the writing consistent with your brand voice? Is the tone appropriate for the task users are trying to complete?

In short, designing with lorem ipsum gives the impression the layout is more important than the content, which is not the case. Before designing or testing mid-fidelity wireframes, collaborate with stakeholders and team copywriters to shape the content first.

items.title: Wireframe Kits
items.content:
Why use a wireframe kit?

A wireframe kit is a collection of components and patterns that can be combined to create wireframe screens. Because they consist of premade elements, they cut down on the time and effort it would take to design elements from scratch.

Wireframe kits also help to establish visual cohesiveness by standardizing color usage, sizing, and overall visual aesthetics. This makes it quicker and easier to collaborate on wireframes while ensuring visual consistency.

More and more designers and design software and tools, such as Sketch and Figma, are making wireframe kits available for free download and usage. There’s a variety of options available, ranging in levels of fidelity, ease of use, and the quality of the kit itself.

You’ll find that some kits are extremely robust and make it easy for customization, while other kits are overly simplistic or even include outdated elements. When searching for an appropriate kit for your project, make sure to do some research and don’t just go along with the first kit you find.

Remember that no matter how much research you put into finding a suitable wireframe kit, you’ll inevitably need to edit or expand on it. Often, you won’t know how you’ll need to add to it until after using it.

A typical scenario is finding that the kit doesn’t include all of the components you end up needing. In these cases, you have a few options. You may create a new component by combining a few of the elements included in the kit. For example, you could design a form from a combination of input fields, buttons, and text. Or, you can follow the standardized styling of the kit to create new elements. Either way, the wireframe kit provides a starting point, making customization easier and quicker to do.

🎬 Using Lorem Ipsem (3 mins.)
Task Scenarios for Usability Testing
items.content:
Scenarios and tasks that engage users

The essence of usability testing is understanding what works and doesn’t in a designed interface by watching people use it. You can gain qualitative insights into where the user struggles so that you can improve the design. To do this successfully, you need to create tasks with good scenarios. These task scenarios need to be realistic, encourage an action, and not give away how to use the interface.

First, ensure you have a list of general user goals that users of your product or service may have. These goals should include the most important things the user must be able to accomplish.

Once you’ve figured out what the users’ goals are, you need to formulate task scenarios appropriate for usability testing. Next, you must provide some context for the user to imagine why and where they perform the task or activity as they interact with your product. This context would be your task scenario.

A scenario gives users context and motivation for why they’re attempting to complete a usability testing task.

“You’re planning a vacation to New York City, March 3 − March 14. You need to buy both airfare and hotel.”

A task is the actual activity a user should attempt to accomplish during a usability test.

“Go to the American Airlines site and JetBlue Airlines site and see who has the best deals.”

Writing good tasks will ensure that you are not testing the user to follow directions but instead focus on how the user interacts with your feature or product.

Make the task realistic

Don’t force participants to act in a way that isn’t natural or engaging for them. Follow their thought process and criteria. If the user doesn’t have the freedom to interact, they may not own the task.

User goal: Browse product offerings and purchase an item.

Poor task: Purchase a pair of orange Nike running shoes.

Better task: Buy a pair of shoes for less than $40.

You can also allow participants to define their tasks if they follow their thought processes and behavior. Ideally, you’d observe them in their environment, but that is usually time-consuming and expensive.

Make the task actionable

The task shouldn’t ask the users to describe what they would do, so they answer in words. Instead, the task should encourage users to act/interact to reach the goal you set for them.

User goal: Find movie and show times.

Poor task: You want to see a movie Sunday afternoon. Go to fandango.com and tell me where you’d click next.

Better task: Use fandago.com to find a movie you’d be interested in seeing on Sunday afternoon.

Avoid giving clues

Avoid giving directions and step-by-step guidance when providing a task. Providing clues or naming interface items produces biased test results.

User goal: Look up grades.

Poor task: You want to see the results of your midterm exams. Go to the website, sign in, and tell me where you would click to get your transcript.

Better task: Look up the results of your midterm exams.

Sample tasks courtesy of Turn User Goals into Task Scenarios for Usability Testing by Marieke McCloskey, Nielsen Norman Group

items.title: How Does the Web Work?
items.content:
Clients and servers

When you visit a web page using a laptop, tablet, or phone, it’s helpful to have a basic understanding of how information appears on your screen.

Computers connected to the web are called clients and servers.

Clients include devices used to access the web–computers, tablets, and smartphones–as well as browsers used to view web content, such as Firefox and Chrome.

Servers are computers that store website files and control how users access them.

A browser requests a web document from a server via HTTP, or Hypertext Protocol. When the server finds the requested file, it sends it back to the browser via an HTTP response.

Parts of a web page

Web pages are typically created by combining three languages.

  • HTML, or Hypertext Markup Language, provides the structure of a web page. Content such as headings, paragraphs, lists, images, and hyperlinks are described to the web browser using HTML.
  • CSS, or Cascading Style Sheets, is used to control the appearance of a web page. Decisions about color, typography, spacing, and layout are determined using CSS.
  • JavaScript is used to add advanced interactivity and behavior to a web page after the HTML and CSS has loaded. If you’ve ever visited a website that loaded new content dynamically, such as Pinterest loading new results when you scroll to the bottom of the page, JavaScript controls this behavior.

Separation of concerns

When creating web pages, it’s important to use the appropriate language for the appropriate task:

  • HTML for structure
  • CSS for appearance
  • JavaScript for behavior

In other words, you won’t be determining how your page looks using HTML, or adding new content using CSS. Following these rules makes web pages easier to organize and maintain, and creates more accessible content for users.

items.title: Intro to HTML
items.content:
What is HTML?

HTML, or Hypertext Markup Language is the code that is used to structure a web page and its content. Headings, paragraphs, bulleted lists, links, and images are understood by our browser once we define them in our HTML.

If we want the following sentence to appear in our browser

Congrats, you are learning HTML!

we need to define its role within our web page by providing markup. Is this a paragraph? If so, we’ll enclose our text in paragraph tags.

<p>Congrats, you are learning HTML!</p>

The opening tag, the content, and the closing tag combine to form an HTML element.

Anatomy of an HTML element

  1. The opening tag consists of the name of the element wrapped in opening and closing angle brackets. Our paragraph element begins here.
  2. The closing tag looks the same as our opening tag, except that it includes a forward slash before the element name. Our paragraph element ends here.
  3. The content of the element exists between the opening and closing tag. In this case, our content is a single sentence.
  4. Our HTML element consists of the opening tag, the content, and the closing tag.

Attributes

Attributes provide additional information about an HTML element.

In some cases, attributes contribute to the functionality of an element. For example, while the <a> element creates a hyperlink, an attribute called href is needed to specify where the hyperlink goes to.

<a href="https://flatironschool.com/">Flatiron School</a>

Other times, attributes are used to give elements an identifier used to target that element with style information.

In the above example, class is the attribute name and student is the attribute value.

Nesting elements

Placing HTML elements inside other elements is common. For example, if we wanted to create a paragraph with some of the text hyperlinked, we can nest the <a> element inside our paragraph element.

<p>I’m learning Product Design at <a href="https://flatironschool.com/">Flatiron School</a></p>

The order of your tags matters! Since we opened the <a> element after our <p> element, we need to close the <a> element first. Closing elements in the incorrect order can lead to errors and other unpredictable results.

Empty elements

While most HTML elements follow the rules we’ve learned, a few elements contain no content and are known as empty elements. Consider the HTML element that creates an image:

<img src="images/student-picture.png" alt="My student profile headshot">

This element requires a minimum of two attributes: src indicates the location of our image file, and alt provides an alternative description for users who can’t view the image. You’ll notice, however, that there’s no </img> tag. That’s because our image element doesn’t surround any content.

items.title: About HTML Documents
items.content:
Anatomy of an HTML document

A typical HTML page might look something like this:

<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <meta charset="utf-8">
    <title>My test page</title>
    <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">
  </head>
  <body>
    <h1>Hello world!</h1>
    <p>Welcome to my first HTML page.</p>
  </body>
</html>

Let’s take a closer look at its contents.

  • <!DOCTYPE html> declares that this is an HTML document.
  • <html></html> declares where your HTML content begins and ends.
  • <head></head> the head of your HTML page isn’t displayed in the browser. Rather, it contains metadata, or information about your page, such as
    • <meta charset="utf-8"> include special characters in your document. Without this line, characters like accented letters and copyright symbols won’t render on your page.
    • <title></title> the title names the page and appears in the current browser tab
    • <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css"> this line attaches a stylesheet to your page, so you can modify the design using CSS.
  • <body></body> the body of your HTML page contains the page contents displayed to your user.

Saving HTML documents

For browsers to understand your HTML file, it’s important to name the file correctly when saving it. Best practices for web file names include

  • Filenames must be lowercase.
  • Filenames must not contain spaces.
    • Separate words with hyphens instead: my-portfolio.html
  • Filenames must only contain a-z, 0-9, hyphens, and dots.

In addition, name your homepage index.html, as this is the page the browser looks for first.

items.title: Semantic HTML: Headings, Paragraphs, Lists, Links
items.content:
Semantic HTML

When choosing HTML elements to present content on the web, the decision should always be made based on the meaning or function of the element, and never what the element should look like. Decisions about presentation, or how the element should look, is the responsibility of your CSS.

Using HTML markup to reinforce the meaning of the information in web pages and web applications, rather than merely to define its presentation or look, is called using semantic HTML.

Benefits of Semantic HTML

  • Semantic HTML is accessible. Users of assistive technologies–screen readers used by visually impaired audiences, keyboard-only navigation performed by users with motor skills disabilities–will have an easier time navigating web pages with correct semantic markup.
  • Improved SEO (search engine optimization). Google uses semantic markdown to understand your content and prioritize search rankings.
  • Easier maintenance. Developers have an easier time maintaining properly structured code.

Headings

HTML includes six heading levels, h1 through h6.

<h1>Most important heading</h1>
<h2>Second most important</h2>
<h3>Third most important</h3>
<h4>Fourth most important</h4>
<h5>Fifth most important</h5>
<h6>Sixth most important</h6>

Best practices for using heading elements include

  • Choose heading levels based on hierarchy of information, not on desired font size. Text can be resized visually using CSS.
  • Avoid skipping heading levels. Start with <h1> for the most important heading, then <h2>, and so on.
  • Use only <h1> per page. Your <h1> element should describe the purpose of the page’s content.

When structured correctly, headings form a table of contents for your web page. Screen readers and other assistive technologies can skip from heading to heading to decide what content to read.

Paragraphs

Use the paragraph element <p> to contain paragraphs of text.

<p>Now she sits alone and remembers.</p>

<p>She sees, over and over, the specters of Tomás Arroyo and the moon-faced woman and the old gringo cross her window. But they are not ghosts. They have simply mobilized their old pasts, hoping that she would do the same and join them.</p>

<p>But for her it took a long time.</p>

Lists

The unordered list <ul> element is used to mark up lists in which the order of items does not matter, like a grocery list. Each individual list item is indicated by an <li> element.

<ul>
  <li>Bread</li>
  <li>Fruit</li>
  <li>Cereal</li>
</ul>
  • Bread
  • Fruit
  • Cereal

Lists can be nested:

<ul>
  <li>Bread</li>
  <li>Fruit
    <ul>
      <li>Apples</li>
      <li>Bananas</li>
    </ul>
  </li>
  <li>Cereal</li>
</ul>
  • Bread
  • Fruit
    • Apples
    • Bananas
  • Cereal

Ordered lists typically use numbers that specify an order like a set of instructions.

<ol>
  <li>Wake up</li>
  <li>Turn off alarm</li>
  <li>Get out of bed</li>
</ol>
  1. Wake up
  2. Turn off alarm
  3. Get out of bed

Links

Hyperlinked text should make sense when read out of context. In the following example, the link text “click here” is not accessible since it is not meaningful on its own.

<p>For more information about Flatiron School, <a href="https://flatironschool.com/">click here</a></p>

A more accessible approach would be to rearrange the sentence so “Flatiron School” is hyperlinked.

<p>For more information, visit, <a href="https://flatironschool.com/">Flatiron School</a></p>

Occasionally the purpose of the link cannot be made obvious by the link text. Examples include a “read more” link at the bottom of a blog post’s introductory paragraph. In that case, an attribute called aria-label can help screen readers and other assistive technologies understand the link.

<p><a href="http://myblog.com/accessible-links.html" aria-label="read more about creating accessible links">Read more</a></p>

items.title: Content Sectioning
items.content:
Content sectioning elements

Content sectioning elements in HTML give meaning to the organization of our pages and create a broad outline for our page content.

With the exception of the <main> element, HTML content section elements may be used multiple times per page, as long as each element accurately reflects the semantic role of the content.

Header

The <header> element is a container for introductory content. Headers often contain logos, search functionality, and navigation.

Nav

The <nav> element contains major navigational links, such as a table of contents or primary website navigation. The navigation links themselves are typically marked up using an unordered list.

<nav>
  <ul>
    <li><a href="index.html">Home</a></li>
    <li><a href="bio.html">Bio</a></li>
    <li><a href="portfolio.html"></a></li>
  </ul>
</nav>

Main

The <main> element identifies the main content of a web page. This helps screen readers and other assistive technologies understand where the main content begins. These assistive technologies can be aided by the presence of an invisible skip navigation link, allowing users to bypass sections of repeated content such as a primary navigation.

<body>
  <a href="#main-content">Skip to main content</a>

  <!-- navigation and header content -->

  <main id="main-content">
    <!-- main page content -->
  </main>
</body>

The content found within the <main> element should be unique to the page, and should not include content that is duplicated across multiple webpages, such as headers, footers, and primary navigation elements.

Each web page should only contain one <main> element.

Article

The <article> element represents a self-contained piece of content that could be shared independently on other websites or social media, such as a blog post or news article.

Section

The <section> element, defined officially as representing “a generic standalone section of a document”, is typically used to group related content within an article. Sections should generally contain a heading describing the content.

<article>
  <h1>The World Wide Web</h1>
  <section>
    <h2>History</h2>
    <p>English scientist Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web in 1989.</p>
  </section>
</article>

Aside

The <aside> element is used for sidebar content; in other words, content that is not the primary content of the page, but is tangentially related to the main content.

The <aside> element serves a similar function as a sidebar in newspaper and magazine layouts.

Address

The <address> element provides contact information, most often for the business or owner of the website. If used within the <article> element, <address> represents the contact information of the article’s author.

Footer

The <footer> element contains footer information such as copyrights, contact information, and links to related content.

Non-semantic elements

Div

In learning more about HTML, perhaps you’ve come across content contained within a <div> element. This element has no semantic meaning, but is typically used to group content that can be easily styled using CSS.

<div id="attention">
  <img src="images/attention.png" alt="exclamation point icon">
  <p>Attention! Here comes an important announcement.</p>
</div>

It’s important to note that <div> elements supplement HTML semantic elements rather than replacing them. If your content forms an article, use an <article> element to indicate the role of that content, not a <div>. You may then additionally choose to provide <div> elements to achieve design or presentation goals.

Span

Like the <div> element, <span> elements are semantically meaningless and are typically used to style content using CSS. The difference is <span> is used to highlight inline elements:

<div id="attention">
  <img src="images/attention.png" alt="exclamation point icon">
  <p>Attention! Here comes a <span class="highlight">very important</span> announcement.</p>
</div>
