items.title: 🎥 Intro to CSS (60 mins.)
Intro to CSS
items.content:
Introducing Cascading Style Sheets

CSS, or Cascading Style Sheets, is a stylesheet language used to describe the presentation of web pages. CSS allows developers to style HTML with colors, font sizes, backgrounds, layout, and much more. Developers also use CSS to adapt content to various devices, screen sizes, and resolutions.

Even before developers write a single line of CSS, however, web browsers apply what’s called a user-agent stylesheet to give HTML elements a minimal amount of default styling.

In the above screenshot, we learn more about the default styles impacting an otherwise unstyled page by right-clicking and choosing Inspect. We can see, for example, that the <h1> element is made both larger and bold by the default stylesheet. We’ll learn more about using the Inspector in future lessons.

Applying CSS

CSS can be applied directly to an HTML element, using a method known as inline styles.

<h1 style="color: blue">Hello, world!</h1>

Or it can be written to the <head> of your document in between <style> tags, using a method known as internal styles.

<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8"> 
  <title>My Web Page</title> 
  <style>
    h1 {
      color: blue;
    }
  </style>
</head>

However, both of these methods are best avoided. By writing your CSS directly in your HTML file, you’re not really separating content from presentation. In addition, developers have to hunt through each individual HTML file to make styling changes, making maintenance difficult and impractical.

External styles

The recommended method of applying CSS styles to an HTML document is using an external style sheet. That way a change to a single style–for example, making the <h1> element red, rather than blue–will impact all HTML files linked to the style sheet at once.

Attaching an external style sheet begins with using an element called <link> in the <head> of your document.

<head>
  <meta charset="UTF-8"> 
  <title>My Web Page</title> 
  <link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">
</head>

The <link> element features two required attributes:

  • rel specifies the relationship between the current document and the linked document. In this case, the linked document is a style sheet.
  • href specifies the path to the linked document.

CSS styles can then be written in the external style sheet:

h1 {
  color: blue;
}

items.title: CSS Rules and Selectors
items.content:
CSS Rules

CSS is a rule-based language. Developers write rules specifying styles that should be applied to particular elements or groups of elements on a web page.

Anatomy of a CSS Rule

A CSS rule consists of the following parts:

  • A selector indicates the HTML element we are going to style. In this case, we are styling the <h1> element.
  • A set of curly braces { } surrounds our CSS declarations.
  • A declaration consists of two parts: a property and a value.
    • A property specifies the aspect of the element you’d like to change, such as its color.
    • A value represents the change we’re making, such as setting the color to blue.

We’ll examine properties and values in future lessons, but for now let’s take a look at different types of CSS selectors.

CSS Selectors

Type selectors

In the example above, we used our CSS selector to target the <h1> element. Selecting an HTML element by name is known as a type selector.

Type selectors will change the style of all matching elements. So if we were to target the <a> element with a type selector:

a {
  color: darkred;
  background-color: lightyellow;
}

This would assign a dark red text color and a light yellow background color to all hyperlinks in our web page. Note that type selectors target element names, not attributes; we didn’t type a href to target our hyperlinks, but simply a.

ID selectors

As you can imagine, styling all matching elements isn’t always practical. What if you wanted to style just one paragraph, rather than all of them?

Fortunately, CSS allows us to target an element’s ID attribute, using what’s known as an ID selector.

<p>This is my first paragraph.</p>
<p id="special">This is a special announcement!</p>
<p>And finally, our last paragraph.</p>

Given the above HTML, we could use an ID selector in our CSS to target only the second paragraph.

#special {
  background-color: lightyellow;
  border: 2px solid red;
}

IDs are designated in your CSS by a hashtag, and the ID name in your CSS must match the ID attribute in your HTML exactly.

One caveat about using id attributes in your HTML: each id must be unique. The following HTML would produce a Duplicate ID error when validating your HTML.

<p id="special">This is a special announcement!</p>
<p id="special">This duplicate ID would cause an error.</p>

Class selectors

If your goal is to target multiple elements with the same set of CSS styles, use a class selector. Class selectors work the same as ID selectors, but they are named in your style sheet with a dot rather than a hashtag, and class attributes can be used as often as you like.

<h2>My Favorite Foods</h2>
<ul>
  <li>Tacos</li>
  <li class="super-favorite">Burritos</li>
  <li>Ramen</li>
  <li class="super-favorite">Falafel</li>
  <li class="super-favorite">Pizza</li>
  <li>Dumplings</li>
</ul>
.super-favorite {
  color: steelblue;
  font-weight: bold;
}

When naming class and ID selectors, avoid spaces and (apart from the initial hashtag or dot) characters other than letters, numbers, and hyphens.

Attribute selectors

The CSS attribute selector is used to select elements with a specified attribute.

<a href="http://myblog.com/accessible-links.html" aria-label="read more about creating accessible links">Read more</a></p>
a[aria-label] {
  color: forestgreen;
  text-decoration: none;
}

The selector above will style any a elements containing the aria-label attribute.

Attribute selectors can also match elements with a specified attribute and value. This can be particularly useful when styling HTML forms. Forms rely on the <input> element to gather data, but the functionality of each <input> element depends on the value of its type attribute.

<form> 
  <ul> 
    <li> 
      <label for="name">Name:</label> 
      <input type="text" id="name" name="user-name">
    </li> 
    <li> 
      <label for="email">Email:</label>
      <input type="email" id="email" name="user-email"> 
    </li>
  </ul> 
</form>

input[type="text"] { 
  border: 3px solid green; 
}
input[type="email"] { 
  border: 3px solid orange; 
}

The above selectors style the form’s text and email inputs differently.

items.title: CSS Properties and Values
items.content:
CSS Properties

CSS declarations consist of two pieces: a style property and its value.

Memorizing a list of CSS properties isn’t a good use of your time. Instead, developers refer to helpful resources, such as

  • CSS Properties Reference at MDN
  • Properties Almanac at CSS Tricks

While there are more CSS properties than can be covered by a single article, you’ll find that many properties fall into a few distinct categories.

Text Properties

CSS text properties and definitions
Property Definition
color Change the color of an element’s text.
font-family Specify the font for an element.
font-size Set the size of an element’s text.
font-weight Set the weight or boldness of an element’s text.
line-height Set the distance between lines of text.
text-align Set the horizontal alignment of text content.

Background Properties

CSS background properties and definitions
Property Definition
background-color Set the background color of an element.
background-image Set one or more background images on an element. Can also be used in creating CSS gradients.
background-repeat Set how background images are repeated.

Box Model Properties

When calculating the size of an HTML element, web browsers include three measurements:

  • Content: the size of the actual content.
  • Padding: the space between an element’s content and its border.
  • Border: a CSS border surrounds an element’s content and padding area.

The fourth measurement belonging to the CSS box model, margin, doesn’t impact the size of an element, but instead represents the space separating one element from another.

Box model properties include

CSS box model properties and definitions
Property Definition
width Set an element’s width.
height Set an element’s height.
padding Set the padding area on all four sides of an element.
border-color Set the color of an element’s border.
border-style Set the line style (solid, dotted, etc.) of an element’s border.
border-width Set the width of an element’s border.
margin Set the margin area surrounding all four sides of an element.

It’s important to note that while padding and margin properties can be applied one at a time (padding-top, margin-left, etc.) it’s often useful to apply all four values at once.

margin: 10px 5px 20px 3px;

The order of the four values always goes clockwise: top, right, bottom, left. In the above example, we’re applying 10 pixels of margin on the top, 5 pixels on the right, 20 pixels on the bottom, and 3 pixels on the left.

Using only one value will apply the same measurement to all four sides:

margin: 10px; /* 10px on all sides */

Using two values will apply the first value to the top and bottom, and the second value to the left and right.

margin: 10px 5px; /* 10px vertical margin, 5px horizontal */

CSS Shorthand Properties

As we saw with margin and padding, CSS shorthand properties allow developers to combine multiple properties into a single line.

For example, the following selector changes multiple font properties for a single ID:

#attention {
  font-weight: bold; 
  font-size: 24px;
  line-height: 150%; 
  font-family: Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;
}

By putting the properties in the correct order, we can shorten this to a single declaration using the CSS font shorthand:

#attention {
  font: bold 24px/150% Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;
}

Helpful shorthand properties exist for background and border as well.

CSS Values

Every CSS property has a set of values it can accept. Depending on the specific property chosen, the acceptable value might be a color, a number, or even a font family.

While memorizing CSS values is once again unimportant, it’s helpful to understand how a few key categories of CSS values work.

Color Values

When assigning a color value to a CSS property such as color, background, or border, you’ll specify colors one of two ways. One is by using a keyword that describes a color, such as black or white, cornflowerblue or tomato. An HTML Color Names resource is helpful in choosing from available colors.

Otherwise, colors are selected using RGB hex values, which begin with a hashtag and use two digits each to specify an amount of red, green, and blue within the color.

Text Properties

Color names and hex values
Color name RGB Hex Value
black #000000
white #FFFFFF
cornflowerblue #6495ED
tomato #FF6347

Working with RGB hex values offers more flexibility than color names. And there’s no need to memorize hex values–tools from Figma’s color picker to online color scheme generators such as Coolors allow you to copy hex values and paste into your code.

Pixel values

Pixels are an example of a CSS length unit. While the term “length unit” may sound confusing, all it means is that most numeric values in CSS can’t exist on their own; you have to specify a unit of measurement. In addition, there cannot be a space between the number and measurement.

Valid and invalid length units
Invalid value Valid value
font-size: 24; font-size: 24px;
width: 360 px; width: 360px;

Pixel values are considered an absolute measurement since they represent a fixed value. If you position your logo 10 pixels from the top of the screen and make it 60 pixels wide, this will remain true regardless of the browser’s viewport size or the device being used.

The device-independent nature of CSS pixels is quite helpful. Even though not all screens have the same number of pixels per square inch, an element measuring 10 pixels in CSS will appear to be the same size whether on a high-resolution screen or a low-resolution screen.

Percentages and Viewport Units

Percentages, on the other hand, are considered a relative measurement, since the size of elements measured in percentages will vary based on the size of parent elements. Relative measurements are helpful in creating responsive web content legible on a variety of devices. For example, setting an image’s width to 100% will allow it to scale with the size of the viewport, or visible area of the web page based on the browser window size.

Also helpful in creating responsive layouts are CSS’s viewport units. Rather than relative to the size of the parent element, viewport units like vw and vh are relative to the size of the viewport. So if a mobile browser happens to be 360 pixels wide, an element with a width of 50vw would measure 180 pixels.

Measuring Type with Em and Rem Units

While it’s possible to determine type sizes using a fixed pixel measurement, many developers prefer CSS’s font-relative measurements, em and rem.

Of the two, rem is arguably easier to understand, since it always refers back to the root font size of your document–in other words, the font-size of your <html> element. If your root font size is 16 pixels, then

  • 1rem equals 16 pixels
  • 2rem equals 32 pixels
  • .5rem equals 8 pixels

and so on.

em works similarly, but rather than always referring back to the root font size, em inherits font sizes from parent elements.

These relative font measurements offer two advantages:

Better accessibility.

Setting the base font size of your document (the font-size of your <html> element) in pixels can actually override local settings of users who depend on larger text to be able to read and interact with your site.

Since the default font size for most browsers is 16 pixels, the two selectors below may seem equivalent, but the version measured using em respects and adapts to the user’s preferences.

Poor vs good accessibility, base font sizes
Poor accessibility Good accessibility 
html {
  font-size: 16px;
}
 
html {
  font-size: 1em;
}

Easier maintenance.

Working with relative measurements makes a responsive CSS type scale easier to create and maintain.

items.title: Working with Web Fonts
items.content:
Web safe fonts

When choosing a typeface for your web page, it’s important to understand how web fonts are loaded.

Historically, developers were limited to web safe fonts when building websites. Working with web safe fonts means choosing a typeface that is likely to be on most users’ devices. The website CSS Font Stack lists examples of common web safe fonts along with recommended font stacks.

Developers typically provide a font stack in case the typeface of choice doesn’t load on the user’s machine:

body {
  font-family: "Helvetica Neue", Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;
}

The above comma-separated list requests that the web page load Helvetica Neue. If that typeface isn’t found, the user’s browser should try to load Helvetica, then Arial, and finally (if none of the choices are found) at least choose a sans-serif typeface.

Note that quotes are placed around any typeface name longer than one word.

System fonts

Working with web safe fonts is pretty limiting, as the list of universally available typefaces is a pretty short one.

A more recent technique used by some developers is a system font stack, which chooses the default font native to the user’s OS: Roboto for Android, San Francisco for iOS, etc. System font stacks offer two key advantages:

  • Fast performance. Since the OS native fonts are already loaded on a user’s device, the web page doesn’t need to slow down to load new fonts.
  • Familiarity. System fonts will feel recognizable to users already familiar with an operating system.

System fonts can be a useful choice for creating legible body copy and for labeling icons.

External web fonts

Web fonts can also be imported from an external source. Using a web font in your CSS consists of two steps:

  1. At the start of your CSS, include a @font-face rule specifying the font to be downloaded:

    @font-face {
  font-family: "fontName"; 
  src: url("path/filename.woff2"); 
}

  2. Then include that font in a CSS rule using a font-family declaration.

    body {
  font-family: "fontName", serif; 
}

Using web fonts typically involves purchasing a license to use that font, and respecting the terms of that license. While an Adobe Creative Cloud subscription includes the ability to load Adobe Fonts, font licenses can also be purchased from independent type foundries.

Working with Google Fonts

The web’s most popular source of free web fonts is Google Fonts.

Working with Google Fonts involves three steps:

  1. Choose the desired weights and styles of your typeface. Choose only what you absolutely need; while Open Sans comes in 12 varieties, for instance, selecting them all will severely slow page loads.

  2. Copy the provided import code and paste into the <head> of your HTML. Google Fonts uses this import code to connect to your desired fonts on the web and to provide a @font-face rule for you.

    Paste the import code above the line in your <head> that links to your own style sheet.

    <link rel="preconnect" href="https://fonts.googleapis.com"> 
<link rel="preconnect" href="https://fonts.gstatic.com" crossorigin> 
<link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/css2?family=Open+Sans:ital,wght@0,300;0,700;1,300&display=swap" rel="stylesheet">
<link rel="stylesheet" href="style.css">

  3. Copy the provided font-family declaration and paste into the desired selector in your CSS file.

    body { 
  font-family: 'Open Sans', sans-serif;
  font-weight: 300; 
}

items.title: CSS Layout and Positioning
items.content:
Display

The display property is one of the most important CSS properties for exercising control over your layout. With it, we can override the default display settings of an element.

As your CSS skills get more advanced, you can use powerful techniques such as Flexbox and CSS Grid to create responsive web layouts. However, in the short term we’ll focus on four of the simpler display values: none, block, inline, and inline-block.

display: none

display: none is most commonly used to hide an element so that JavaScript can reveal it later. If you’ve ever seen a blog post where pressing ‘Read more’ revealed the rest of the article, it was most likely initially hidden using display: none.

Note that content using display: none cannot be accessed using assistive technologies, so it’s not an appropriate method for creating a skip navigation link.

display: block

Many of the HTML elements used to mark up text, like headings, paragraphs and unordered lists, have a default display value set to block.

Block elements occupy 100% of the width of the available space by default and are placed underneath each other, not side by side.

display: inline

The best known HTML element that uses a display value of inline by default is the <a> element, since text links often appear within body copy.

Inline elements will be on the same line as other content. And it’s impossible to increase the width or height of an inline element using CSS.

display: inline-block

display: inline-block is a bit of a mixture of the previous two display types. While inline-block elements will be on the same line as other content, you can set the width and height of an inline-block element using CSS.

While display: inline-block was once a common choice for styling navigations, these days it’s typically replaced by more modern methods such as Flexbox.

Position

By default, the position of elements on the page is determined by the normal flow of content in the HTML document. In other words, if you have a heading with a paragraph beneath it, and a bulleted list below that paragraph, that's exactly the order that content will appear in the browser.

This is referred to as static positioning, and position: static is indeed the default positioning for HTML elements. In addition, there are a few other position types that can help you solve layout challenges.

position: absolute

Elements set to position: absolute are removed from the normal flow of the document, and are positioned based on the values of top, right, bottom, and left.

#logo {
  position: absolute;
  top: 10px;
  left: 5px;
}

In the above CSS, the element with an ID of logo would be removed from the normal page flow and placed 10 pixels from the top edge of the viewport and 5 pixels from the left edge of the viewport, unless impacted by the position of a parent element (see below).

position: relative

Since elements set to position: relative are also positioned according to the normal flow of the document, in most cases relative positioning isn’t so different from static positioning, with two exceptions:

  • Changing the position to any value other than static introduces the ability to use z-index on an element, allowing developers to stack elements on top of one another.

  • If an element is set to position: relative, child elements set to position: absolute will be positioned based on the parent element rather than on the edges of the viewport.

position: fixed

The fixed position value works similarly to absolute. Elements are removed from the normal flow of the document, and are positioned based on the values of top, right, bottom, and left.

However, as the name suggests, fixed elements also remain in place when the page is scrolled. This is useful for creating a fixed header or footer.

Use caution with this technique on mobile screens. If you create a large fixed element, you won’t have much room for your remaining content.

position: sticky

Sticky positioning works like a mixture of relative and fixed positioning. Elements set to position: sticky will behave like a relative positioned element until a user has scrolled past a certain point in the viewport.

#sticky {
  position: sticky; 
  top: 0; /* become fixed when at the top of the viewport*/
}

At that point, the element becomes fixed until the user scrolls back past that point in the opposite direction.

Float and clear

In magazine layouts, it’s common to position an image to the left or right and allow text to wrap around it. Floats in CSS are designed to achieve the same effect.

#img-left {
  float: left;
}

#img-right {
  float: right;
}

Occasionally, you’ll want to prevent content from wrapping next to a floated image, which is where clear comes in.

<img src="kitten.jpg" 
  alt="kitten sitting in a basket" 
  id="img-left">
<p>Lorem ipsum dolor...</p>
<p class="clear">Duis aute irure dolor...</p>
#img-left {
 float: left;
 margin: 0 1rem 1rem 0; 
} 
.clear {
 clear: both; 
}

items.title: CSS Cascade, Specificity, and Inheritance
items.content:
Settling CSS Conflicts

In our first CSS lesson we learned that CSS stands for Cascading Style Sheets. And while we’ve discussed working with style sheets at length, we’ve yet to cover the letter C. What makes our style sheets “cascading”?

In this reading, we’ll cover the rules that determine how the browser behaves when it encounters conflicting style rules. Understanding these concepts will save you lots of frustration when you begin styling your websites.

Cascade means that the order of CSS rules matter.

The CSS cascade means that when two CSS rules have equal specificity, the one that comes last in the CSS will be applied.

<h1>Hello world!</h1>
h1 {
  color: red;
}
h1 {
  color: blue;
}
Hello world!

Specificity settles conflicts when different selector types target the same element.

When CSS uses specificity to settle conflicts, it means more specific selectors take priority over less specific ones. In the below example, even though the color blue is applied last, the more specific class selector takes precedence.

<h1 class="main">Hello world!</h1>
.main {
  color: red;
}
h1 {
  color: blue;
}
Hello world!

While the complete rules regarding specificity can get complex, it’s helpful to know that

  • ID selectors are more specific than class selectors
  • Class selectors are more specific than type selectors

CSS Inheritance

Some CSS properties are inherited, meaning the element's style values are copied from its parent or containing element.

<p>This is a <em>really interesting</em> sentence.</p>
p {
  color: green;
}
This is a really interesting sentence.

In the above sentence, part of the text is emphasized using the <em> element, but we didn’t specify that the emphasized text should be green. The text is green anyway, because text color is an inherited property. The element inherits the text color from the parent element, the paragraph.

Not all CSS properties are inherited, however. For example, applying a border to a parent element won’t create an additional border around its child element.

For a list of inherited CSS properties, see CSS Inheritance: An Introduction.

items.title: Responsive Design Principles
items.content:
What is responsive design?

Responsive web design describes an approach in which content and navigation adjusts based on the device viewing the web page.

The term “responsive web design” was coined in 2010 by Ethan Marcotte in an article for A List Apart. In his article, Marcotte identified three components as key to creating responsive web content:

Fluid Grids

On phones, there’s only room for one column of body copy, which extends all the way across the screen. On tablet and desktop screens, designers can base their designs on a multi-column grid layout that can expand or contract based on the width of the device.

Flexible images

Images and other multimedia content such as videos should expand and contract along with your responsive grid.

Media queries

Media queries are CSS rules that get implemented under certain conditions. For example, you might want to switch from a one-column layout to a multi-column version once the viewport, or visible area of the web page within the browser, is wider than 600 pixels.

When media queries are used to adjust the site layout based on the width of the viewport, this is known as a breakpoint. Breakpoints shouldn’t be based on the dimensions of specific devices, but instead determined by the needs of the content itself:

“Design the content to fit on a small screen size first, then expand the screen until a breakpoint becomes necessary. This allows you to optimize breakpoints based on content and maintain the least number of breakpoints possible.” – Pete LePage and Rachel Andrew, Responsive Web Design Basics

Working Mobile First

Typically, designers and developers prefer to solve for the smaller mobile viewport first. Working mobile first has a number of benefits:

Identify the most critical content

The amount of content that can be viewed on a phone without scrolling down is limited. Considering the small screen first forces designers to make decisions about what should grab the user’s attention first.

Faster loading time

Loading only what’s absolutely necessary on a mobile screen means the mobile version of your web page will load faster. Which is important, since studies suggest that over half of page visits are abandoned if a mobile site takes longer than three seconds to load.

However, unless content is purely decorative, use caution when deleting content from your mobile experience. Just because content is of secondary importance doesn’t mean it’s safe to remove it entirely.

Solve complex navigation challenges

Due to limited screen real estate, creating effective and intuitive mobile navigation is more challenging than solving for larger viewports.

A popular mobile pattern is the tab bar. Users recognize it quickly, and it can be kept on the bottom of mobile screens to be easily reached by the user’s thumb.

For navigation with more than five primary sections, designers are likely to find themselves weighing the pros and cons of using a hamburger icon to reveal navigation options. When designed well, users should recognize the function of the menu icon, and it’s definitely a space saver.

However, keeping your primary navigation options hidden reduces discoverability. If a feature isn’t immediately seen, users might assume it’s of lesser importance or even totally absent.

Variations of this pattern include using the burger menu for secondary functionality only. In Uber’s mobile app, key features such as the map and the search bar are immediately available, while secondary options like history and settings are hidden behind the hamburger menu.

A number of news websites with numerous primary navigation options use a pattern called Priority Plus, where the number of visible navigation options depends on the width of the screen. The Guardian makes sure the most common categories are visible at all times, while hiding additional categories beneath a collapsible menu icon.

Responsive Body Copy

Web body copy should be kept a minimum of 16 pixels. Beyond this rule, recommendations for the optimal presentation of body copy can vary a bit, but the Visual Presentation entry of the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines states that blocks of text should follow these rules:

  • Width no more than 80 characters per line
  • Text should be left-aligned, not justified
  • Leading should be at least 1.5 times the height of the text
  • Paragraph spacing should be at least 2.25 times the height of the text

On mobile devices in portrait orientation, respecting these guidelines is reasonably straightforward. But as viewports get wider, keeping body copy a maximum of 80 characters per line grows more challenging.

Potential solutions for larger screens include

  • Using larger body copy
  • Increasing white space
  • Switching to a multi-column layout

items.title: Responsive Images
items.content:
Working with responsive images

Try Googling the term “responsive images”, and one of the top results is an article at W3 Schools that seems to suggest working with responsive images on the web is pretty simple. All we need to do is follow two rules:

  • Set the image width to 100% so it can scale with the viewport
  • Unless your intent is a full screen hero image, make sure there’s a max width established to prevent images from growing unnecessarily large on a wide screen

But is that really all there is to it?

In many cases, yes. However, as you prepare your images for the web, there are two things to look out for that make working with responsive images not quite as simple as it sounds.

File sizes

We’ve learned previously that studies suggest that over half of page visits are abandoned if a mobile site takes longer than three seconds to load.

With that in mind, consider this adorable stock photo of a kitten:

You might be tempted to include this image at its original resolution. After all, higher quality is better, right?

The problem is, at its original resolution of 6000 x 4000 pixels, this kitten JPEG weighs 2.6 megabytes. Multiply that times the number of images found in a typical product design case study, and you’d get a web page that nobody will ever see.

Selecting image sizes

So how do designers and developers choose the correct image size? While the answer can be both varied and quite complex, one possible method is

  • Calculate the largest size your image will possibly be viewed at. This will be determined by the max width declaration used to prevent your images from growing too large.
  • Double that size to account for high-resolution retina displays with screens featuring increased pixels per square inch.

If your maximum image size is 1000 pixels, we’ll reduce our kitten image to 2000 pixels wide to account for retina displays.

Let’s say after using an image editor to scale our kitten JPEG down to 2000 x 1333 pixels, we’ve reduced our image to 367 kilobytes. That’s an 86% file size savings! Good, enough, right?

Enter the image compressor

Online image compressors such as TinyPNG can shrink file sizes even further with minimal reductions in image quality. For example, TinyPNG reduces our 2000 x 1333 pixel kitten JPEG down to 218 kilobytes.

Source: TinyPNG

 

While the additional savings might seem insignificant–what’s another 150 kilobytes or so?–each step taken to speed up website performance makes a big deal to impatient mobile users.

Art direction

The other issue with responsive images is commonly referred to as the art direction problem. While square images often look good on a variety of devices (thus their popularity on social media sites like Instagram), extreme landscape images are another story. While wide images might look great on a desktop or laptop computer, they become difficult to decipher on a mobile screen in portrait orientation.

Designers and developers account for this issue by providing two separate sets of images: one with more squarish proportions for the mobile screen, and a wide landscape image for computers.

An additional benefit to this approach is, once again, download times. The cropped image aimed at mobile devices will download much faster than the larger landscape image.

Naming your images

When saving images for the web, there are a few important naming conventions to follow so web browsers will load your file correctly.

  • Filenames must be lowercase.
  • Filenames must not contain spaces.
    • Separate words with hyphens instead.
  • Filenames must only contain a-z, 0-9, hyphens, and dots.
  • Keep filenames descriptive, which helps with Search Engine Optimization (SEO).
    • card-sort-with-post-its.jpg is helpful, my-photo.jpg is not.

items.title: CSS Media Queries
items.content:
What are CSS media queries?

CSS media queries are special CSS rules that detect information about the way your web page is being viewed. The CSS rules written within a media query will only be applied if certain conditions are met.

Media queries aren’t really used to target specific devices. You wouldn’t use them to control how your design looks specifically on an iPad Air, for instance. Which is a good thing, as new devices are introduced constantly, and code written for each device would be impossible to maintain.

Instead, media queries are used to target more general characteristics about the way users view your web page.

Media queries are typically kept at the bottom of your CSS document, since they should be executed last.

Anatomy of a media query

While the specifics of a media query might vary depending on the developer’s intentions, the basic structure of a media query looks something like this:

  • Declaration: media queries begin with an @media declaration. Notice there’s no space between the @ symbol and the word media.

  • Media type: most of the time you’ll be targeting devices with screens, which means screen is the most common media type.

    However, media queries can also be used to create print style sheets. When designing a web page that users might have a compelling reason to print, it’s a good idea to use a print style sheet to hide content that won’t make sense on the printed page or might otherwise waste paper.

    @media print {
  nav {
    display: none; /* hide navigation when printed */
  }
}
  • Media features: what are the conditions under which the CSS rules inside the media query should be applied? CSS offers a wide range of targetable features, but we’ll just cover a few of the basics here.

Targeting CSS media features

min-width

The most commonly targeted media feature is min-width. This has to do with a mobile-first approach. Developers use their base CSS rules to style web pages for mobile devices, then test their solutions by expanding the viewport until their design is no longer effective. Any place where web layouts need adjusting to read effectively on a larger viewport is known as a breakpoint.

For example, you might determine that your layout looks good until the viewport grows as wide as 600 pixels. 600 pixels would be your first breakpoint.

@media screen and (min-width: 600px) {
  /* CSS rules for screens 600px and wider */
}

If your design then looks great again until the viewport is at least 960 pixels wide, add another breakpoint at 960px.

@media screen and (min-width: 960px) {
  /* CSS rules for screens 960px and wider */
}

Note that we’re not using the term phone, tablet, or computer here. We’re making adjustments every place our design becomes less than optimal, and not worrying about specific device screens. This is one reason why communication with developers is critical, since breakpoints are determined in tandem with designers and developers working together.

orientation

Sometimes you’ll want to adjust your web layouts based on whether users hold their devices in portrait or landscape orientation.

@media (orientation: landscape) {
  /* CSS rules for landscape orientation */
}

resolution

While you won’t query for resolution often, occasionally you might improve the experience of users of high-resolution devices by serving them higher quality images.

@media (min-resolution: 150dpi) { 
  #hero { 
    background-image: url('../images/hero-hi-res.jpg');
  } 
}

items.title: CSS Flexbox
items.content:
History of responsive development

Prior to 2007, very few strategies existed for mobile web design or development, since until that point no device allowed for a satisfying mobile browsing experience.

With Apple’s 2007 launch of the iPhone, developers found themselves scrambling to create mobile-legible layouts using the technologies available at the time. A common hack was creating responsive grids based on CSS’s float and clear properties, even though neither was designed for this purpose.

Eventually CSS added two powerful layout tools designed to arrange responsive elements within the viewport: Flexbox and Grid. While both have their uses, Flexbox is arguably easier to learn as it arranges elements in one dimension at a time: either as a row or as a column.

Using Flexbox

Using Flexbox begins with setting a parent element’s display property to flex. The direct children of the parent element become flex items, meaning they now have the ability to move, expand, or contract to fill the available space within the viewport.

#flex-container {
  display: flex;
}

As the above GIF illustrates, nothing visually dramatic happens immediately to flex items. The flex items are now arranged along a horizontal axis. The direction of the axis can be changed using the flex-direction property.

  • flex-direction: row is the default value, and arranges flex items on a horizontal axis.
  • flex-direction: column stacks flex items vertically by arranging them on a vertical axis.

justify-content

The arrangement of flex items along the main axis depends on the value of the justify-content property.

  • justify-content: flex-start is the default value, and groups flex items at the start of the axis.
  • justify-content: flex-end groups flex items at the end of the axis.
  • justify-content: center groups flex items in the center of the axis.
  • justify-content: space-between places the first flex item at the beginning of the axis and the last flex item at the end of the axis, then distributes the remaining items evenly.
  • justify-content: space-around distributes flex items with equal space around them. However, the space before the first item and after the last item is only half of the space separating the remaining items.
  • justify-content: space-evenly works similarly to space-around, but the space surrounding all items is equal.

align-items

align-items works extremely similarly to justify-content, except that it affects the arrangement of items along the cross axis. If your flex items are arranged along a horizontal axis, align-items deals with their vertical arrangement.

While flex-start, flex-end, and center work identically to their justify-content equivalent, align-items has two values worth looking at more closely.

  • align-items: stretch stretches flex items to fill the container.
  • align-items: baseline aligns items based on their content baseline.

flex-wrap

By default, the flex-wrap property in CSS is set to nowrap, which forces flex items all fit into one line. If you’d prefer your flex items to wrap onto a new line as the viewport grows narrower, set the flex-wrap property to wrap.

flex-grow

So far, we’ve worked with aligning our items within a flex container, but we’ve left their sizes alone. What if we want our elements to change sizes along with the viewport?

flex-grow provides the ability for flex items to scale if necessary, and dictates the amount of available space each item in the flex container should occupy.

If all flex items have a flex-grow value of 1, each item will take up an equal amount of space within the flex container–even if that means overriding an existing width declaration.

However, if one flex item has a flex-grow value of 3, and the remaining elements are set to flex-grow: 1, the larger element will take up 3 times as much space as the remaining flex items.

Note that unlike the previous properties covered so far, flex-grow belongs on the flex items themselves, not the parent element.

#flex-container {
  display: flex;
  justify-content: space-between;
}

.flex-items {
  flex-grow: 1;
}

Resources

For more on using Flexbox, bookmark the helpful Complete Guide to Flexbox reference at CSS Tricks.

Also, check out Flexbox Froggy, a fun and memorable game for learning Flexbox properties and values.

items.title: Introducing Material Design
items.content:
What is Material Design?

Material Design is a design language developed by Google in 2014 with a goal of creating a consistent experience for Android app users with predictable interactions and app behaviors.

The best place to learn more about Material Design as well as keep up to date with changes in the guidelines is by using the official documentation at https://material.io.

This is particularly important because, as of the time of this writing, Material Design is currently migrating from version 2 to version 3. The docs can be used to help you keep up as Material Design evolves.

Is Material Design a design system?

Material Design’s documentation feels like a design system, but it functions differently in important ways.

If you were building an app for Adobe, for example, you’d be expected to follow the guidelines from Adobe’s Spectrum design system closely. You would use the specified fonts, colors, spacing, and usability cues while being careful to reflect Adobe’s branding and adjust any written content until it’s consistent with Adobe's voice and tone.

The goal of Material Design, however, is to create predictable user experiences with predictable interactions. The Google Play Store won’t reject an app for failing to apply the Material Design visual language. In fact, one of the key features of Material Design is called Material Theming, with a stated goal to “customize Material Design to match the look and feel of your brand.”

The store will reject an app, however, if certain usability expectations are not met. For example, the Back button in an Android app allows users to navigate recently viewed screens in reverse chronological order. Assigning unexpected actions to this button would be confusing to Android users anticipating one predictable behavior.

Matching user expectations

If you’re building an app to be sold in the Google Play Store, your app doesn’t need to be designed to look like Gmail. However, you should study the Material Design docs to get a sense of what behavior and interactions Android users are used to.

And if an interactive pattern familiar to Android users is appropriate for your content, you need to understand the dos and don’ts for implementing that pattern.

items.title: 🎬 Material Design (6 mins.)
🎬 Using Material Design (2 mins.)
Material Design Principles
items.content:
Material is the metaphor

The appearance and behavior of Material Design content is inspired by two real-world materials: paper and ink.

Virtual paper

Imagine your phone containing layered sheets of paper pressed between the device in your palm and the glass covering the screen. Tapping onscreen buttons might cause these layers to rearrange or summon new layers of paper from offscreen.

Every layer of content in a Material Design app exists on a sheet of virtual paper. Each sheet of paper is exactly one dp (or "dip") thick. Dp is short for density-independent pixels. Dps are flexible units that scale to have uniform dimensions on any screen, which allows for consistent designs across a variety of devices. So, for example, a 48 by 48 dp button would appear to the user to occupy 48 square pixels on the screen, no matter how high the device’s resolution.

Virtual paper can be as small as a button or grow large enough to fill the screen. Virtual paper can split apart into smaller shapes, or heal into one large sheet of paper.

Otherwise, virtual paper behaves like physical paper. The paper casts shadows, suggesting depth. A sheet of paper closer to the user should cast a longer shadow than paper farther away.

Just like physical paper, one sheet of virtual paper cannot occupy the same space or pass through another sheet.

Virtual ink

Each layer of paper contains content: text, images, videos, and more. Material Design imagines this content as virtual ink decorating each sheet of virtual paper.

Ink can move independently within a sheet of paper, forming any shape imaginable. Or it can move and scale with the paper. But ink cannot exist independently of a sheet of virtual paper.

Ink has no depth and doesn't impact the shadows cast by paper.

Bold, graphic, intentional

Material Design’s second guiding principle, “bold, graphic, intentional”, means that Material Design prefers bold, bright colors. However, it’s more important for designers to represent a brand accurately than to choose a bold palette.

According to Material Design’s Applying color to UI page, the most important rules to remember when applying color are the following:

  • Be consistent. Apply color consistently throughout a User Interface, and keep color choices compatible with the represented brand.
  • Be distinct. Use color to create a distinction between interactive elements, and make sure foreground and background have sufficient contrast.
  • Be intentional. Rather than making arbitrary color choices, use color to convey meaning, such as relationships between elements and degrees of hierarchy.

Motion provides meaning

Material design provides three principles for using motion within an Android app.

  • Keep motion informative. Use motion to highlight the relationship between interface elements, to inform users what actions are possible, or to clarify the results of an interaction.
  • Keep motion focused. Apply motion minimally to focus attention on what’s important. Superficial motion should be discarded.
  • Keep motion expressive. Reflect a brand’s personality, add character to common interactions, and celebrate the achievement of a user goal.

items.title: Material Design Patterns
items.content:
Understanding common Material Design patterns

It’s not necessary to style an Android app to look like other apps designed by Google. However, Android users are used to applications behaving in a certain way. To design an effective Android app, it’s critical to familiarize yourself with common Material Design interface patterns, and understand how they differ from iOS interactions.

This reading isn’t meant to be a definitive guide to Material Design interface patterns. Additional patterns are covered in the Components section of the Material Design documentation.

Floating action buttons (FABs)

One of the most recognizable Material Design interface components is the Floating Action Button, or FAB. A Floating Action Button gets its name because it appears to float above other layers of content, casting a longer shadow.

A Floating Action Button is used to perform the primary action on a screen. In an email application like Gmail, the FAB would be used to compose a new message.

Floating Action Buttons are contextual, meaning the action performed with a FAB might change from screen to screen. And not every screen needs one.

While a maximum of one Floating Action Button per screen is recommended, Google Maps uses two: one to get the user’s location, and one to launch the directions screen.

Floating Action Buttons are permissible only for constructive actions: create, share, explore. Actions users might wish to undo, such as deleting a file, shouldn’t be accomplished with a FAB.

Bottom navigations

Bottom navigations are a convenient navigation choice for mobile apps. They’re quickly understood by users, and they’re near the user’s thumb, making them ergonomically friendly.

However, using a bottom navigation in an Android app means understanding the rules guiding the implementation.

  • Use for 3-5 top-level destinations. If your application has fewer than 3 main sections, or more than 5, use a different pattern.
  • Be consistent. The navigation should use the same icons, labels, and placement on every screen.
  • Apply color meaningfully. Highlight the currently active link, keep the contrast high, and don’t use multiple colors within the navigation bar.
  • Use icons AND text wherever possible. An icon combined with a brief label is more meaningful than an icon alone.

Navigation drawers

For apps with more than 5 top-level sections, or with multiple levels of content hierarchy, a navigation drawer might be an effective choice.

A navigation drawer saves space by remaining hidden until the user interacts with a menu icon.

As pictured above, navigation drawers are typically opened from the left. However, if the navigation drawer is activated by tapping a link in a bottom navigation bar, it should instead appear from the bottom of the screen.

Groups of links can be separated by a horizontal divider. Text labels alone are acceptable for naming links, but text plus an icon may be even more usable.

items.title: Human Interface Guidelines: A Brief History
items.content:
1987

Apple’s Human Interface Guidelines have been publicly available since before the launch of the World Wide Web. In 1987, Apple released a textbook aimed at creating a consistent interaction experience for users of Apple and Macintosh computers.

The principles outlined in Apple’s 1987 textbook should sound pretty familiar to product designers today:

  • Consistency: Visual consistency makes it easier for a user to learn new applications
  • Feedback: When a user performs an action, the system should provide immediate feedback communicating the results in plain language
  • Control: The user, not the computer, should control the initiation and completion of actions at all times.

2007

In 2007, Apple revolutionized mobile browsing with the launch of the iPhone. While browsing the internet using a mobile device was possible before the iPhone, the experience was inefficient and not particularly satisfying.

Apple’s iPhone introduced a number of innovations users take for granted today, including

  • Replacing the physical phone keyboard with a touchscreen interface
  • Allowing users to scroll quickly by swiping up and down
  • Allowing users to zoom in using a pinch gesture

The iOS design of 2007 was heavily skeuomorphic. Skeuomorphism refers to user interface elements that mimic a real-world object. The calculator from the first iPhone features shiny highlights and deep shadows suggesting raised plastic buttons–a clear example of skeuomorphism.

How about the flatter buttons featured on more recent iOS calculators? While the 3D appearance is gone, this is still a skeuomorphic design, as the arrangement of the buttons will still be familiar to anyone who has used a physical calculator.

While the faux wood and leather textures of the first iOS may look dated to modern eyes, the reference to everyday objects like bookshelves and desktop calendars offered usability clues to users who prior to 2007 had never encountered a smartphone.

2013

The launch of iOS 7 in 2013 represented a shift in Apple's design aesthetic. Gone were the decorative textures and the illusion of depth, replaced with a slicker flat design.

While flat surfaces reduce clutter and speed loading time, not everyone embraced Apple’s new approach. Don Norman, User Experience Architect at Apple from 1993 to 1998, and co-founder of the Nielsen Norman Group, wrote a 2015 editorial in Fast Company Magazine criticizing Apple's flat design as concealing affordances in favor of a minimalist style.

“Apple is reinforcing the old, discredited idea that the designer’s sole job is to make things beautiful, even at the expense of providing the right functions, aiding understandability, and ensuring ease of use.” – Don Norman, How Apple Is Giving Design A Bad Name, 2015

2017

The 2017 release of iOS 11 saw Apple address criticisms of flat design by embracing what's been termed Flat 2.0.. While iOS 11 featured a more minimal design than the first iOS, interface elements are no longer entirely flat. Subtle highlights, gradients, and shadows, indicate depth and signify clickability.

This semi-minimalism with hints of depth is still a part of iOS 15, the most recent operating system at the time of this writing.

2022

In June 2022, Apple launched a completely reorganized version of its Human Interface Guidelines documentation.

The content is now broken into six top-level categories featuring details for designing and developing for a variety of iOS platforms:

  • Foundations
  • Patterns
  • Components
  • Inputs
  • Platforms
  • Technologies

When designing an iOS app, it’s best to bookmark this resource and refer to it frequently.

items.title: 🎬 Human Interface Guidelines (7 mins.)
Working with Human Interface Guidelines
items.content:
Understanding user expectations

Apple’s Human Interface Guidelines are not, strictly speaking, a design system.

Your goal in using the guidelines isn't to create an app that reflects Apple’s branding, but rather to understand the expectations of iOS users, and come up with an app that reflects your client's brand, while remaining functional and accessible, legible and usable, across a variety of iOS devices.

Working with Apple’s Human Interface Guidelines means referring to the official documentation frequently to understand user expectations and current best practices. Therefore, this reading isn’t intended to be a comprehensive overview of the guidelines, but rather a gentle introduction.

Designing for iOS screens

Apple offers recommendations for mobile devices that make usability easier for all types of users, including making sure content is legible and functional in both portrait and landscape orientation (which is also a WCAG accessibility requirement) and keeping interactive controls at the bottom of the screen, near the user’s thumb, whenever possible.

In addition, the Human Interface Guidelines offer guidance on “safe areas” for making sure your designs allow comfortable margin and aren’t covered by elements such as the device frame.

In addition, designers might consider what onscreen content gets covered when the iOS keyboard is displayed.

System icons and fonts

Even though your goal when designing applications for download in the App Store isn’t to match Apple’s branding, there are times when using native iOS design elements makes more sense than applying custom styles.

SF Symbols

When using icons within your application, it’s worth considering the value native icons provide before spending time creating your own custom icons. Apple’s library of native icons is known as SF Symbols.

For example, when offering users the ability to mute or unmute a sound, users will be quicker to recognize the native symbol than a custom icon. Creating something custom doesn’t really offer a lot of value when compared to the potential frustration this may cause.

When designing iOS apps, it’s best to use custom icons only for custom actions–ones whose functionality isn’t neatly described by a native icon found in SF Symbols.

System Fonts

While the typography of your app will generally reflect your product’s branding, there are certain situations where using a system font offers advantages:

  • System fonts require no loading time since they’re native to the user’s device.
  • System fonts feel familiar to the user.
  • System fonts are designed to remain legible at small sizes.

Apple’s system fonts include a serif typeface family called New York and a sans-serif typeface family called San Francisco.

In situations such as labeling interface icons where legibility is more important than creating a brand-specific experience, consider making use of Apple’s system fonts.

Using Apple design resources

When designing iOS apps that take advantage of common Apple design patterns, designers can speed up their design process by making use of templates and wireframe kits.

As of the time of this writing, the official Apple Design Resources page limits its support to Adobe XD and Sketch, meaning no Figma resources are provided. But a bit of creative Googling can lead designers towards helpful resources in Figma’s community, such as this iOS 15 UI Kit for Figma.

items.title: Human Interface Guidelines: Patterns
items.content:
Implementing iOS patterns

Just as app designers aren’t required to reflect Apple’s branding when designing an app, they similarly aren’t strictly required to rely on iOS patterns when designing interfaces and helping users accomplish tasks.

However, using patterns familiar to iOS users can help reduce cognitive load. When users encounter a familiar tab menu or list of sharing options, and that interface has been implemented in accordance with the Human Interface Guidelines, users should understand what to expect when using the interface. And using a pattern improperly–ignoring the guidelines for implementing an existing pattern–can cause an app to be rejected from the App Store.

There are a vast number of interface patterns found in the Human Interface Guidelines documentation, and the documentation gets updated periodically, so this reading is intended as a gentle introduction, not a comprehensive guide.

Tab bars

Tab bars work well when an application offers 3-5 mutually exclusive sections of content in the same view.

Tab bars are designed to enable navigation, not help people perform actions. When users need to perform an action relevant to the current view, use a Toolbar instead.

Tab bars typically work best using a recognizable icon chosen from Apple’s SF Symbol library, combined with a brief text label using Apple’s San Francisco system font.

Navigation bars

When Apple’s Human Interface Guidelines describes navigation bars, it doesn’t mean an area of the page featuring primary navigation, like you might find on a website. Instead, the iOS navigation bar provides the title of the current screen accompanied by a back button. It may also feature context-specific controls helping users accomplish a select task.

For example, in the default iOS email app, users viewing their Inbox are provided with a back button returning them to their choice of mailboxes, as well as an Edit button allowing them to select one or more messages to perform an action such as Move, Delete, or Mark as Read.

Activity views

Activity views are often called a share sheet, since users typically encounter them when sharing content via text messaging, email, or social media. An activity view presents the range of tasks or sharing opportunities available once a user selects an item (such as a hyperlink, a photo, or a document.)

The Human Interface Guidelines strongly recommend using the Share icon to activate sharing options, and to use an Activity view to present all possible sharing activities.

Providing an alternate sharing method might confuse users of your app.

Action sheets

Action sheets present choices related to an intentional action. For example, when people cancel a Mail message they’re drafting, an action sheet provides 3 choices:

  • Delete the draft
  • Save the draft
  • Return to editing

Action sheets should be used sparingly. They’re a great way to seek confirmation for a potentially destructive action, such as losing an email draft in progress. For actions of less consequence, however, action sheets can be too disruptive.

Note that action sheets serve a different function than alerts. Alerts interrupt a current task to call attention to a problem or seek user permission for a feature such as geolocation. Alerts are often not triggered by user activity and are usually unexpected, whereas users learn to expect action sheets when performing certain activities.

items.title: Mobile vs. Desktop Usability
items.content:
Comparing environments

Many readings comparing design for mobile environments versus the larger desktop screen focus on the challenges of designing a user interface that fits the smaller screen.

And that’s understandable. Desktop screens have space to display complex, multi-tiered navigation schemes all at once, but mobile screens don’t. Mobile screens lack the space to place multiple columns of body copy side-by side. And the amount of space above the fold to capture user attention with important content is far more limited on mobile screens.

But there’s more to creating a great mobile experience than simply adjusting content to fit the screen and solving navigation challenges. What aspects of the experience of using a mobile device are different from the experience of using a computer?

Mobile devices are, well...mobile

This one sounds obvious, but people use mobile devices on the go, which creates a set of unique challenges and opportunities that don’t face people using computers.

  • More distractions. While providing context clues letting users know what page they’re currently on and how to get around is helpful on any web page, it’s especially critical on mobile, where a user’s attention can easily be distracted by a surrounding environment, a phone call or text message, or a notification from a different application.

    Mobile users are also more prone to connectivity issues, so mobile applications should save progress whenever possible and allow users to resume a previously attempted task without starting over.

  • Changing locations. The good news for app developers is that geolocation, or the process of using technology to find a user’s current location, is far easier on mobile than on a computer.

    On the other hand, this means mobile users often depend on geolocation as part of an effective experience, providing accurate directions, weather, and local search results.

Additional features and considerations

  • Different inputs. While the mouse and keyboard are the primary tools used for navigating on the computer, mobile devices are powered by taps, gestures, and voice commands.
  • Push notifications. While notifications are part of the desktop experience, mobile notifications harder for users to miss. They’re a powerful tool for gaining user attention, but also a potential source of distraction or annoyance.

  • Photo and video capabilities. It’s far easier for a mobile user to record and share a photo or video than a computer user. Mobile apps sometimes use this capability in creative ways, such as scanning credit card numbers using the camera to save the user from having to physically type them.

  • Privacy and security concerns. Mobile devices are more susceptible to being lost and stolen, and contain far more personal data than a computer typically would.

items.title: 🎬 Design Across Devices (17 mins.)
Multi-Device Experiences
items.content:
Considering multiple platforms

Discussions about responsive User Interface design tend to center around websites. When designing a website, it’s important your content remain legible and usable across desktop and mobile devices.

When it comes to app design, however, the number of potential environments increases greatly. While it’s not necessary or even advisable to design your app to function in all platforms, it’s worth considering whether any of the following make sense for delivering your product’s content:

  • Tablets. Tablets are a part of responsive design, of course, since users browse websites with them. When it comes to designing applications for tablets, however, it’s worth noting that tablets are often shared by multiple family members. Tablets store less personal data, and their applications tend to be more entertainment-oriented.

  • Wearables. Wearables most often take the form of smart watches. Smart watches feature extremely small screens and offer limited navigation possibilities. However, smart watches excel at tracking health and fitness data, and can perform tasks associated with smartphones, such as receiving calls and sending text messages.

  • Smart TVs. Designing for a TV is pretty different than designing for a mobile device. The screen remains in a fixed place, while users navigate content using voice commands or a remote control while seated an average distance of 10 feet away. TVs have less memory and processing power than phones or computers, so interfaces need to be kept somewhat simple.

  • Virtual Reality (VR) and Augmented Reality (AR). Augmented reality presents users an augmented version of their normal reality, whereas virtual reality replaces the user’s reality with an immersive virtual environment. For more on these emerging technologies, check out New Realities: VR, AR, MR, and the Future of Design.

Designing multi-device experiences

From health applications like Apple Health to entertainment applications like Netflix, one common feature is the user’s ability to seamlessly transition from device to device. A jogger can run a mile with their Apple Watch on knowing that data will be recorded on their iPhone, while a Netflix viewer can pause the latest episode of Stranger Things on their living room TV, then resume watching in their bedroom using their tablet.

What principles can designers apply to create effective multi-device experiences? In her book Designing Multi-Device Experiences, UX Designer and author Michal Levin suggests what she calls the 3Cs Framework for operating within a fully connected world.

Consistent

When creating multi-device experience, consistency refers in part to understanding and following the expected interface and usability patterns for each device.

If your application attempts to innovate by deviating from the established pattern, make sure that innovation adds significant value for your users. Otherwise you’re increasing cognitive load unnecessarily.

Consistency also refers to creating a familiar experience for your brand no matter the environment. To create this consistency, designers and developers need the guidance of a design system.

“A design system breaks down the UI into reusable parts and creates a system of interactions that users can recognize across devices. An experience like a share flow should be cohesive across devices, but also across applications in an ecosystem.

With a design system we can really focus on the ecosystem, which includes the experiences of all the products across the brand and all of the devices from which they are accessed.”

– Sarah Federman, Adobe design engineer

Continuous

As mentioned previously, a Netflix user expects a continuous experience when switching between devices. However, since these devices also accept a variety of inputs from users, a multi-device experience should also be flexible enough to adjust for transitions between user inputs.

A multimodal system is one in which users might switch inputs to enter information–for example, using a remote control to begin a search, then switching to a voice command. In some cases, a switch might occur as part of the system output, as when a system responds to a voice command not with a voice response, but with a list of onscreen search results.

Some designers refer to these moments of transition as interaction cliffs, since a poorly handled transition risks losing context, time, data, or (depending on the nature of the interaction) even jeopardizing user safety.

Complementary

A complementary experience occurs when different devices are able to collaborate as a linked group or control one another.

The Nest thermostat can be controlled physically by touching its screen. Equally effectively, the user can choose from a variety of devices to interact with the Nest from a different room or a different location entirely, and Nest data will be recorded to the user’s Nest application.
